commentBody:
Deb:

Arkansas. Not Arizona.
New personal best for a Friday. Seemed a bit on the easy side.

FUNFILLED Friday. 
No RANT, not a DUD, but I'm not sure ILOVEDIT.

(Where will solves fall on the BELLCURVE?)

Thank you, Jesse.

Signed,
A CUSTOMER

The two-tailed figure I thought of first was the Starbucks mermaid, who is apparently actually a siren. But very similar to figures I saw painted on the wall of a very very old church in Greece. And then I misread the clue for MANDARIN and thought the answer had to be the four postal abbreviations in alphabetical order. That slowed me down in that corner! Other than that, it solved very smoothly.
Don’t really think I’m the first here tonight, but close to it. Had a fairly smooth solve, but liked the puzzle. Most of my trouble was in the SW.
IDLEST? Harrumph.

Shout out to all the TILers here.
Cruciverbalism feeds AUTODIDACTicism.


Do emus prefer EVOOs?
Evade, elude. Some kind of library dust? I couldn't remember ronin, I had rough approximations of a lot of it. Tried Full of fun before it had to be fun filled.

There was a FUNFILLED puzzle, with lots to like.  I, for one, liked the clue for BELLCURVE, and the use of AUTODIDACT, NOCAP.

I also liked THECREATIONOFADAM.  Though not a religious person I was very moved by the frescoes in the Sistine chapel.

Seeing BBKING took me back to when I was 12 or 13.  My best friend’s mom worked at the Lawrenceville School, and when BBKING performed a concert there, she insisted on taking us.  Neither of us knew much about him, and were, of course, blown away.  My somewhat unlikely intro to the blues.The funny thing was that my friend’s mom was a very refined lady whose musical interests lay in the classical sphere.  Thinking back, I recall a couple of years earlier, she took us to see A Hard Day’s Night. So her outward appearance concealed hidden depths.  Many years later I learned that she had driven an ambulance in France during WWII.  She’s still going strong at 101 and still does the NYT crossword in ink every day.

This seemed like a tale of two puzzles to me. Half seemed very easy with early week level clues and half was extremely out of my element.  RAPBATTLERS spit rhymes? I’m assuming that’s a slang term for what they do? AUTODIDACT and NOCAP was a true Natick to me—no complaint I learned a new word that actually describes me and it makes sense. On the flip side MUNSTERS was a gimme and sad to admit so was CLEO, what kind of a Disney nerd do you have to be to know that? Overall a satisfying solve.

The CONE. Starring our Claudius.

“NO CAP, this thing is a DUD.  NEIN, I will not tolerate it! I’m an unhappy CUSTOMER. FUN-FILLED, this ain’t.  I LOVED IT - not!!! I am gonna RANT about this horrible DEED all night!”

And in the morning: there he was, no cone.
An AUTO-DIDACT and he’s not telling how he got it off.

DDD before DUD

Took me forever to sort out the SW corner, as I had Creation of Eden crossing veNT, and irks before ills, but I got gold eventually.

Took a bit of time but I got it.   Nice play on words in some of the clues.  After about 5 years of solving, I can say it’s finally become rare that I need to look anything up to solve a puzzle, even on the tough days.   I’ve come a long way since those first weeks of solving when I’d never get a Thursday-Sunday puzzle without look ups.  So if you are new at this, just keep plugging away.

Is this the SMURFaissance? Three times this week. Any puzzle referencing BB KING is okay by me. Fell down a rabbit hole with him after solving. Here he is live with Bobby Blue Bland. My dad had a CD of them performing together that we both loved. https://youtu.be/fUyKrNzW3Pc?si=Sbr27oZuI6F-Gc2n

Nice puzzle but I found it surprisingly easy for a Friday.

🤷‍♂️

Mandarin was a nice answer.  I didn't love the clue for bell curve.  Ah well.

30A.

Scut Farkus?

...

Emu stuck to icy post.

This was a perfect puzzle for me and my level of competence.

After I'd made a pass (I don't go in linear fashion--I try to build off of a seed of a cross or two at some place in the puzzle) I was really unsure if I'd seen anything that I could make a decent guess at, looking at the sparsely filled in puzzle.

Then I'd get another one, which would give me another letter or two to work with.  Then it happened again.  Then again.  Find a mistake there (RANT, not veNT) and more came tumbling out.

I just love solves like this.  I almost feel like I used to feel when I was in great shape after a long run.  The headache I had at the start of the run  was gone, the fatigue was delicious, my breathing fast, not labored but deep and relaxing, and my frame of mind just couldn't have been better.

I miss those days, and enjoy it when I get a whiff of it through a good crossword.

This is all to demonstrate that the grump I was a couple of weekends ago when I face-planted on Saturday and Sunday was not my only facet, for what it's worth.  I am sorry about that.

I wouldn't say this one was FUNFILLED for me, but ILOVEDIT anyway.

Good job, Jesse. Always nice to see you.

I guessed the wrong Kennedy, but I then immediately realized that  a reference to the specific rap battle between two self-proclaimed Jewish-American princesses from the musical comedy TV show Crazy Ex-Girlfriend from eight years ago was an unlikely answer to the cross.
Chart and graph are not synonymous in the sense of 21A. Graphs represent a function, whereas charts plot some data. There is no PIE graph.
Really good stuff.
My Diary of a Crossword Fiend review: https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/08/28/friday-august-29-2025/#ny
Great puzzle, just challenging enough. Thanks!

Unlike Deb, I didn't pray that the middle letter of 34A wasn't another D. Nope, I confidently filled in DdD. I mean, if you believe God CREATed ADAM, then he must also have created DdD cups, right? What's the big deal? Does he also create DUDs? Loved CELESTIAL EVENT. I saw three shooting stars this summer at Dead Horse Point State Park in Southern Utah, which were three more than I'd ever seen before in my 60 years of life. I was always that person going, "Where? Where?" any time someone else noticed one. I'd forgotten that Herod shows up in the Christmas story. As I recall, he was also a singer and dancer. I'm sure I won't be the first commenter to link to these... https://youtu.be/KHHfeCgERnE?si=n_zOYqyQCtDbJ9Kw Or https://youtu.be/9BnxwP8vLRg?si=nO0X7SKTueaW67sP Or... I was going to link to this year's Josh Gad version at the Hollywood Bowl, but apparently, it's been taken down.
I still have to use auto correct for Friday and Saturday, but that was a fun puzzle!
I’m sorry but 44 across not clicking for a daily slack user. IMS is not a synonym for DMS and ALL slack messages are instant by design
I like this one! But SMURF? And a PIE graph? But some really nice long fills and good clues.

The gift-packaging competition was a wrap battle.

(It got present-tense!)

You didn't think autodidact was a tricky clue? It's certainly not part of my normal vocabulary. I really only got it with the crosses after correctly guessing the "seriously in slang" clue (I am, after all, 76 years old.) Anyway, completed without having to resort to help.
As per my byline, I’m not in Puyallup. It’s a treat to open the comments with only 44 comments to peruse. Even so, I have nothing to add!

Oh my. I had an error in mine that I finally got corrected. I had misspelled CLEO initially as CLiO. That left me with Di_ for [Start to do?] I thought to myself, the NYT can’t possibly have DIL as the answer here, right?!?! 😳 I finally got the answer to [Eclipse, for one]. Oh, DEE!!  🤣🤣🤣😅 Phew! I must have giggled at myself for 10 minutes. Thank you, Jesse, for a FUNFILLED experience on my end. 
Happy Friday. Enjoy the long weekend!!!

Excellent puzzle. Started off with very much nothing but little by little it came together. 

Never heard of EVOO as a term and quite honestly I hope I never do again. Why would you need to shorten the original. Are you in a rush to say it? How do you even pronounce it? Internal monologue leaking out. Sorry. 

Nice to see the SMURFs making a return.
Sorry Deb. In MANDARIN, AR is the abbreviation for Arkansas, not Arizona. Arizona is AZ.

LOL. 34A "Big bust." I had DDD. A big bust indeed. 
I was lucky to get the word going down to correct it.

A very enjoyable Friday.   Even though I didn't know a lot of the answers I was able to deduce them once I got enough of the crosses.   Examples: Smurf,  autodidact, Tau, Ronin, Cleo.     My brain was apparently working well tonight, as I got the music in about 60% of my average time.
SMURF have been appearing quite often, with the 2nd entry this week (IIRC) and in the Mini today.
Anyone else read 46D (haha, D) and immediately hear in their head "cut a hole in a box..." (Just me? I'll see myself out)
Re: 18A—I’m still thrown by “consecutive” in the clue—was that necessary to include? Argh…

For me an "Autodidact" is not likely to frequent a library and would prefer to learn in a solitary fashion via the Internet.  Traditionally one of the main features of a library was the librarian, whose job was largely to assist users in finding information.

Started this last night when I really should have been asleep and got the usual result: stuck, stuck!, stuck!! (H/T to another Christmas Story) For me the puzzle is about as good an indicator of how I'm doing taking care of the "little grey cells" as anything I've found. This was a fine workout once I invested the requisite zzzzz's. I'll leave with this: "A politician is an elected or appointed official focused on gaining and maintaining power, often through partisan strategies and self-interest. A statesman, in contrast, is a highly respected leader who prioritizes the long-term common good, acts with integrity and magnanimity, and serves the entire political community rather than a narrow faction. The term "statesman" implies a much higher level of moral character and public service than "politician". " https://www.nationalaffairs.com/publications/detail/a-time-for-statesmanship
At [Start of some temple names], who else confidently threw in BETH instead of BNAI?
A breeze for me except for the southwest...just couldn't see rap battle.

Nice puzzle. Typical tough Friday for me and had to look up a couple of things but ended being an enjoyable workout. Kind of surprised to see five debut answers in this one and at least three of them quite familiar terms - e.g. SWINGSETS, FREEMEALS etc. No big deal.

Answer history search today was inspired by BBKING. Dawned on me that THETHRILLISGONE is 15 letters. It's been an answer in 3 puzzles - one of them a Thursday from July 16, 2015 by the great Paula Gamache. Four grid-spanners in that one and two of those never appeared in another puzzle - and the other one was only once before in a pre-Shortz puzzle. Those were: 

LETDOWNYOURHAIR
PSYCHOLOGYTODAY
ILLDOITTOMORROW

A bit surprised by that. I'm done. 

...

I got stuck in the bottom right corner. EVOO is an acronym I've not met before. Midas isn't a company that's well known in the UK and "muffler" v "silencer" is a difference between Amlish and Britlish I hadn't been aware of. I think I've seen NO CAP once before in the Nyt xword but it hasn't stuck like TSA, ICEE, EDYS and  other more common answers.

Got it all on the first pass through except for the intersection of EVOO and NOCAP, neither of which was familiar to me. Upon my return, I just plugged in what I thought were the most likely letters, and voila, jingle!

I made two mistakes on today's puzzle that slowed me down considerably. First, I discovered (fairly quickly, thankfully) that, although "avid reader" fit very nicely, it was "autodidact" that was wanted. Second (and this one is all on me), the famous painting is not called "The Creation of Eden."

Enough of making Fridays too easy! I realize the Times is trying to sell games subscriptions, but I miss when Fridays and Saturdays took some time to muddle through. I’m not looking to get through a puzzle as quickly as possible, I’m looking for a challenge at the end of the week.

Random thoughts:
•	The two stars, IMO, were the largest answers, CELESTIAL EVENT and CREATION OF ADAM.  Both are gorgeous to look at in the grid as well as in real life.  
•	Oh yes, Jesse has constructor mind, he who can look at MANDARIN and see four state abbreviations.
•	It takes guts for a constructor to put DUD smack in the middle of the puzzle.  But, as of yet, no commenter has used that word to describe it.  
•	About time you showed up in the Times puzzle, EVOO, after appearing in other venues more than 30 times over the past 20 years.
•	Lovely to see neighbors PIE / TIN.  
•	I, who usually don’t enter answer until I’m quite sure of it, had a fair number of take-out-and-replaces today. That, to me, is a sign of a skillful cluer.
•	Personal PuzzPair© of MANDARIN (as in orange) and I’LL BITE.

Enough rub to satisfy, enough fun to send me sprightly into the day.  Thank you for this, Jesse!
An enjoyable puzzle. It took me a little while but I got it done. I have never heard of nocap or evoo but I had the intersecting clues .

Pardon me if someone has already mentioned this, but regarding the new and “improved” way of displaying replies to posts: There doesn’t seem to be a “Share” button in that new mode. I would hate to see that functionality taken away.
Difficult but doable. Friday delivers again. Actually this week has been great for puzzles. Knock on wood.
Four stars.

EVOO just irritates me unreasonably. I can't explain it or justify it, but it does. My wife was the daughter of an angry, notoriously demanding German chef...imagining him using EVOO just warps my mind. "Chef" and "cute" don't coexist in my view of the universe. I suspect that whoever came up with it never set foot in a restaurant kitchen.

I couldn't get BBKING. I was running the song through my head, and some portion of my brain was shouting the answer at me, but KILLERBEE as a guard to a queen bee is unknown to me, and since I had B__ING I wanted to see a vowel in there somewhere. It was the only thing I looked up. I always imagine B.B King lyrics in italics, and I was even imagining the italics, but the double consonant prevented me from making the final connection to that part of me that already knew.

I once had a girlfriend who went, alone, to a B.B. King concert. She sat right at the edge of the stage. At one point, he walked over, squatted right in front of her, looked into her eyes, and said (and I have to paraphrase):

"I thought I had her wrapped around my little finger. But, after a while,I knew that she had me wrapped around her little finger."

Then he played a long lick on Lucille, and said:

"And I liked it."

One look, and he knew.
Delightful

A fairly brisk Friday for me as I finished in around half of my average time. Fortunately, the long fills .. CREATION OF ADAM and CELESTIAL EVENT came to me immediately. I also loved their juxtaposition as they are similar in their grandeur. I had never heard of EVOO, though I managed to get it easily enough by the crossing fills. I did enjoy the clueing for CANON, “What fan fiction is not.” I thought it was quite sly. 

Though I actually look forward to tough end-of-the-week puzzles and I breezed through this, I did enjoy it. I don’t necessarily think it was easy, it was just that I was on the constructor’s wavelength. Because the XW gods may think I’m cocky now, tomorrow I’ll probably end up tearing my hair out over the grid.
If your DEED DENTs my DISC and turns it into a DUD with a capital DEE, I might insist that you DUBAI me a new one.

Fun fact: It seems that Pinocchio (1940), the second animated Disney feature film, is the first to have a named “cute animal” character (not counting Mickey Mouse short subject personas.) Snow White (1937) had lots of animals, but only named the cute little men, of whom I was thinking when saw the 47A clue. 

As to the whole puzzle, who can’t stand back and admire Creation of Adam paired with Celestial event, and Bell curve with Pie (graph); Herod described as a “Christmas story villain”, to name a few of the delectable entries?
Mr. Cohn hints at hackneyed hyperbolic descriptions, Fun filled; I loved it--!!! optional. And his telegraphic recipe for Hollywood success: Meet Cute. But he adds equally telegraphic diagnoses of old car problems and what I consider online-comment problems: RUST and RANT.  Papa couldn't have put it better. Yep, I did love it.

I enjoyed this, especially clues like 'Queen's guard' and the 'two tails'. 

There are nearly always clues I solve with crossers but am unfamiliar with: I know SWING but not SWING SET, I didn't know TEE OFF meant 'anger', can't work out how 'big bust' means DUD. 

ROBES hanging in a hotel room? Judges and mayors wear robes - but on looking that one up, I find it means 'dressing gowns' ....

No connection to:
"Give me my robe, put on my crown: I have immortal longings in me." from Cleopatra.

The clue about a 'coaster' immediately reminded me of 'Cargoes' by John Masefield:
Dirty British coaster with a salt-caked smoke stack,
Butting through the Channel in the mad March days.

Can you tell I'm from the generation that learnt poetry off by heart for homework?

What a fun puzzle this was!  As ever, I fell into the clever traps and misdirections,  but enjoyed saving graces as a result of watching all those cooking shows, not to mention taking Art History.
I get entries like SMURF and MUNSTER only through the crosses...  unable to regret not having been exposed to those.
And what, pray tell, is wrong with LOVE stories that begin with a MEET CUTE?  (DHubby and I have a story there....)

Ahem.  The Queen Bee is attended by a group of Worker bees (all female, of course) who groom, feed, and guide her as she does her duty:  laying eggs.  Workers (who perform many important functions) also guard the entire HIVE; they are not specifically guarding only the Queen, and none are specifically designated as KILLER BEES, for Pete's sake.  Have some respect!

Had to guess between EVADE and ELUDE as I didn't know those crosses.  I guessed wrong at first (of course!) but luckily the rest of the puzzle was correct.  Also had WORKER bee before KILLER bee.

Fun puzzle and a good level of difficulty.  Many thanks, Jesse.
17 Across: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=APUWOoUqQho
Well, we know they don’t mean RFK Jr.
Great cluing Jesse Cohn! The culmination of an excellent week of puzzling!

Today's brain fog:
Why was Deb concerned that the middle letter of D_D might be a third D?
So I googled DDD.
Google was not much help.
Degenerative Disc Disease?
Domain-Driven Design?
Defined Daily Dose?
Diners, Drive-Ins and Dive?
Strange things to concern Deb and "The Gray Lady"!

It was only when I read some comments here that the "bust"-related meaning came to mind.
And in retrospect, I'm glad that Google didn't understand my query.  I really don't need to start my morning with a triple-D bust search.

I guess I was the DUD (with a capital DEE) this morning.

AR is the postal code for Arkansas not Arizona…. I know you’ve been to Arkansas, Will, because I met you when I attended the puzzle day at the Clinton Presidential Library. That was a lot of fun; I even made it to the finals! Come back to Little Rock AR again (not to be confused with AZ) 😄

I didn't get much on my first pass. In the beginning there was ADAM and EVES.

I'm sure we can all agree that "Christine" was the greatest movie ever because that AUTO DID ACT so well! Yet somehow she was beaten by Shirley MacLaine for Best Actress?!?!

Course I know what AUTODIDACT really means cause I meself am self-learnt.

Nice Friday puzzle! It was done except for a distressingly empty NE because "normal CURVE" wouldn't fit. Suddenly the meaning of "Queen's guard" transformed--one of those pleasurable moments that keep me coming back--and the rest of that quadrant fell with a satisfying thud.

That's was a toughie, but not exceptionally so, as my time was only 8% longer than usual.

The SW and SE were problem areas for me.  Thinking of OPEN for 48D may have been coincidentally what opened up the SW.  And I can't believe how I finished this puzzle.  I had six unfilled squares scattered in the SE, and not feeling good about any of my possibilities for them, I just, without thinking or stopping, filled them in and got the gold star.  What a relief.
Why does Adam have a belly button in that painting? You had one job, Michelangelo...
Deb, AR is Arkansas. AZ is Arizona.

For that terrific quote in the extreme southwest, I went from FDR (guess when nothing else filled) to KENS changing to MLK to FREEMEALS changing to JFK to an unimaginable result for a spitting contest for 51A.  This is not 1943 anymore!  But crosswords have odd stuff in them sometimes.

I didn’t get the music went to list view and the slur seemed even more stark, particularly after the Hiroshima and Nagasaki 80th solemnity.

Then RFK hit me.  Still remember listing to my little transistor radio in bed late one night in June 1968 when that horrible news hit, which I understood… I remember 1963 but was too young to get it.
Great puzzle and I enjoyed it very much…would love to know the title of the book

RE: 55 Across.

Stop. Just.... stop trying to be young and hip. 

Gen Alpha slang is not for you. It's not for any of us.

It’s nice to know that there NYT has fixed the issue of comments that don’t show up for hours (if at all). 

(Yes, I am being sarcastic. A number of wholly innocuous comments that I wrote around 4 or 4:30 CDT when I couldn’t sleep are still not showing at 9. It’s discouraging.)

Some will complain that the puzzle was too easy, but 49A !!  Autodidact - what a great word.  Maybe I'm responding to subliminal cues like 40A and 49A, or I just like the aesthetics of the long answers.  Best puzzle in awhile.

SWINGSETS brought back memories of the old swing set we had in the back yard when I was a  kid. It was basically 2 steel A-frames with a cross piece header where all the swings, etc were hung from. 
It wasn't actually attached to the ground so if you could swing high enough you could actually get the legs to come off the ground and make the swing set walk.
Very dangerous in hind site, but it sure was fun!
Great puzzle! Really fun. Four stars!

This is a bit off topic, but I'm in December 2017 in the archives and there's discussion in Wordplay of the then-upcoming crossword cruise on the QM2. Did any of you regulars attend? I'm curious how many folks were on board, and how it went. Sounds like it would have been right up my alley, and I gather it hasn't been repeated.
I love the puzzles within clues like MANDARIN. Couldn’t quite think of it without any crosses but sure had fun trying.
I was so stuck on "Vent" for blow off steam and irks/ires. It took deleting ''I'm sure I'm right" answers to see the possibilities and correct answers.

This felt like a good mix of gimmes, tricky clues, and don't-knows: perfect for a Friday. 
One of my favorite things about crosswords is the brain's ability to be confidently wrong. For example, I misread "peel" as "peal", as in RINg, giving a Christmas villain named HEROg. "Yeah, that sounds right." 😂
My other favorite thing is the diversity we bring to solving. Different generations, regions (even countries), life experience, all brought together by our love of puzzles. One person's "gimme" is another's "don't know", and we all learn something new! (AUTODIDACT is new to me, but I knew EVOO thanks to Ms Ray!)
That was awesome. A perfect Friday. Kudos!

Set my Friday record with my first sub-10 time. Not sure if this one was generally easy or it just all came together for me this week. Really liked the clue for MANDARIN, you could do a whole trivia round where the answers are all spelled from US postal codes.

With the opening letters MAN for the language I filled in MANDINKA for some reason. It was RIND that set me straight before realizing Kansas in KS not KA. 
My puzzle solve filled in fairly smoothly from NW to SE which left my final square, the O of NO CAP like a shot in the dark as I’ve never seen EVOO nor the slang before.

My first rap battle, I was set to destroy my opponent, but (un?)fortunately it was love at first sight instead.

So I sang:

Pleased to meet cute
Hope you like my spit
But what's puzzling you
Is wherefore I rap like--

Long story short, I lost the battle, but won the war of love.
Excellent puzzle.  Mandarin is like Secretariat at the Belmont.

Cleo, yes, the name finally popped into my head when filling in the 'C'.

My kids absolutely loved a video that was a collection of songs from older Disney movies. They sang and danced to it, endlessly, it was a great rainy day distraction.

'Cleo was a little bitty fish...'
'Figaro looked at Cleo with hunger in his eyes...'

In those days, these songs were my earworms, and today at least, I'm sure I'll find myself humming this one again...

'But that's the tale of a kitty and a fish,
Figaro, Figaro, Figaro...and Cleo'.
 
Oh dear! Lol

Fun Friday!  Thanks.  
I put down “Bee” for “Start of do”, thinking beehive [hair]do.  Overthinking it and with another answer having bee in it, not a good choice.  
No Cap is not going to show up in any of my convos.
A thoroughly satisfying Friday crossword, one of the hardest Friday in memory.
Kind of surprised that is the debut of EVOO

Am teaching most of the morning this semester, so won't be getting to some of these puzzles until mid-afternoon.

Solved this one unaided, but it took me quite some time. Being drained from teaching might have played some role, or maybe the puzzle was especially challenging. It certainly seemed to be a very solid Friday puzzle.

NOCAP appeared recently enough that I remembered it. MEETCUTE still makes no sense to me, as a word or as a device, but I must have seen this one too somewhere.

"Certain graph shape" for PIE strikes me as odd. I'd expect "chart" rather than "graph" there. 

OK, let's see what the rest of you thought.
We’re just gonna ignore MEETCUTE?
Tough! Rewarding! Thought I'd never break into this one. Needed some help, but finished eventually. I liked BELLCURVE, SWINGSETS, and AUTODIDACT immensely.
NYT, did you get a deal to subliminally promote "Smurfs" or something? Because "SMURF" has been the answer to three different clues this week, and once on the Mini!
Graphs and charts are two distinct things. Pretty bad clue for 21A when there were countless options that weren't objectively incorrect.
What's up with SMURF in all the puzzles lately?
I enjoyed this puzzle a lot. Thought it was going to be easier than it was when I got the fist three across right away. Ha! I should have known, there’s no such thing as FREEMEALS. 😉

Oh, this was a good one. It started out slow and sporadic for me, and I had a flashback to my earliest crossword days when I'd have a little freakout - "ARGH! I'll NEVER solve this!" But I chipped away with some guesses, many of them wrong at first, until eventually the rubber hit the road. There were a lot of interesting words and clues today, a cut above what we usually see, I think. Thanks for the fun!
I was today years old when I discovered He-Man and She-Ra ave the same number of letters, and that neither was the foe of Gargamel.
Excellent puzzle all round.  My only quibble is that there’s really no need to clue MIDAS as a brand name.

Dreadful puzzle. I cannot believe people liked this. I have been playing the Times crossword for years and nearly always solve without lookups, I have a probably above average vocabulary and there were so many words or entries I had never heard of before. 

And then there is this one: Plot device in many a Rom-com: MEETCUTE?

Challenging for me, just as a Friday puzzle ought to be. My last and toughest spot was the slang NO CAP crossing STEP. I’m seldom aware of current slang but I really should have seen STEP sooner. That’s on me. Thanks for the fun, Jesse Cohn.

Somehow was in sync with this one, felt easier than normal except for the spit: rapbattle clue. Favorite was the mandarin clue, only because it reminded me of a comedy bit by Gary Gulman on how the states got their two-letter postal codes. https://youtu.be/dLECCmKnrys
Hands up if you had JFK and wondered how *AP BATTLES could possibly be an answer.
Nothing clicked with me on this one.  It makes me question my brain power. Oh well. Now where did I put my phone...
My fastest Friday time. Felt like a Tuesday.
Not my wheelhouse but getable, made for a nice Friday challenge. I liked it.
Why is a mare a stable mate? Isn’t a stallion also?
@Steve L Yup. The As are among the hardest postal abbreviations to remember. Arizona isn't AR, Arkansas isn't AK and Alaska isn't AL.

@Francis

Wait a minute.  8 out of 50 is 16%.  Are you testing us?  I can multiply by two, no factorials needed.   :)

@B

Well, wait, did I err?  How many M states are there:

Maine
Minnesota
Michigan
Maryland
Mississippi
Missouri
Massachusetts

Did I miss one?

I did.  Montana.

You are correct and I am flat out wrong.  I miscounted the number of M states.

By the way, that you immediately recognized the trick about "multiplying by two" in this case (sans factorials 😀) demonstrates to me that you have a keener sense of math than you let on.

That kind of insight I think predates the calculator era.  Now the question " 8 out of 50 is what %"  brings out the calculators.

So, I'd appreciate the favor if you chose to believe I did it to test you, (especially having bragged about factorials--man, this is almost biblical punishment).

But I actually just messed up.

@Steve L

Yeah, I kept getting those two abbreviations mixed up during our road trip this summer, as we visited National Parks in both Arkansas and Arizona.

@Susan D

That was hilarious.

@Beth in Greenbelt

Dead Horse Point would be a great place for a meteor shower. 10 or 20 years ago, we were out at Delicate Arch in Arches NP and stayed well after sunset. 

I don’t know if you know that hike, but a good part of it is across open slickrock that has a pretty good slope. Halfway down, there was a meteor shower and we just lay on the slickrock (which was still warm) and saw dozens of shooting stars.

If you’ve never seen a meteor shower where they’re coming every few minutes, it’s worth the effort. We were in Creede, Colorado, when the Perseids peaked a few weeks ago, but it was too cloudy to see anything.

@Kevin D I had a relative who lived in that town. It looks like PULL YA ALL UP. Where does this unusual name come from?
@Kevin D LOL, same. I love a morning solve and reading the early comments while the US is asleep. It's such a fun assortment of people, serious cruciverbalists and non-native English speakers.

@Ms. Billie M. Spaight
The name comes from the Puyallup tribe native to the area! In the Lushootseed language, "Puyallup" (spuyaləpabš) roughly translates to "generous people". A lot of cities in Washington are named after the indigenous tribes of the area, and can definitely be hard for non-Washingtonians to pronounce first try. Hope this helped! :)

@Jane Wheelaghan

They are here as well, although we usually call them scarves. 

Funnily, Google’s AI interface provides the answer to the difference between the two:

A muffler is a vehicle part that reduces noise and exhaust emissions, while a scarf is a piece of fabric worn around the neck, head, or shoulders for warmth, fashion, or other purposes. In some parts of the world, like the US, the term "scarf" is more common for the clothing item, and "muffler" is an older term for a winter neck accessory that provides insulation.

43% of users solved slower than their Friday average.

It is a beautiful poem, and starts:

Quinquerime of Ninevah, from distant Ophir,
Rowing home to haven in sunny Palestine,
With a cargo of ivory,
And apes and peacocks,
Sandalwood, cedar wood, and sweet white wine.

Have a look at his Sea-Fever:

I must go down to the sea again, to the lonely sea 
     and the sky
And all I ask is a tall ship and a star to steer her by.

Romantic and of its time, my father could quote these too.

"A British coaster being a species of ship never crossed the NYT puzzle, I’ll bet." Right you are, Suzzzanne. "You are clear
O rose, cut in rock,
hard as the descent of hail.
[...]"

The prof said, "if you memorize a poem you will own it." Didn't happen.

@Xword Junkie - "Meet cute" is a movie industry phrase that dates back to the 1930s. Romantic protagonists can't meet in an ordinary way - the must meet cute (e.g., she absent-mindedly hits his ball on the golf course; he's shopping for a pajama bottom as she's shopping for a pajama top, etc.)

@Drew

If you look up pie chart it says it’s a type of graph. I think there’s the very tight definition of graph which suggests x and y axes and a looser definition which suggests any visual representation of data. It’s fair to use the second.

@SP just because a term is misused so often that the misused definition enters common language, doesn't mean it's a good clue. Words have meaning and it's quite annoying to just make up new definitions for words.

Graphs and charts are still two different things and it's improper to use them interchangeably.
@Drew - Clues are hints, not definitions. If a clue leads you to the correct answer, it's a good clue.
@Peter C. That is a very helpful perspective. It may tamp down my own occasional fits of pedantry.

@Drew
As a STEM education researcher, I partly agree with you. I would not say they are distinct because 'charts' is a broader term that includes 'graphs.'

However, I would agree that a pie chart would not generally be considered a graph. Although M-W defines "graph" a bit more loosely than I was taught back in the day, a pie chart still does not quite fit (because it uses area to compare quantities rather than to compare variation).

Graph
1: a diagram (such as a series of one or more points, lines, line segments, curves, or areas) that represents the variation of a variable in comparison with that of one or more other variables
2: the collection of all points whose coordinates satisfy a given relation (such as a function)
3: a collection of vertices and edges that join pairs of vertices

That said, I had no trouble figuring out what was wanted by the clue.
@Drew, it's not misused. If you look at any elementary school math unit on graphs, you'll find pie chart/pie graph.
